= That email you sent‚Äîdid you sound stupid?

Stop Replaying, Start Interrupting

That email you sent‚Äîdid you sound stupid? Your brain won't let it go. Here's why.

It's 3AM. You're lying awake, replaying it. "Why did I say that? They probably think I'm an idiot. I should've just kept my mouth shut."

You know it's irrational. You know you should just let it go. But your brain won't stop.

You scored {{ $('Webhook').item.json.query.quiz_score }}/10 on the quiz. That's not just "overthinking." That's a pattern.

Here's what's actually happening:

This isn't anxiety about the future. This is shame about being seen.

Therapy helped me understand why I do this. But it couldn't stop the loop at 3AM. Because shame operates pre-consciously‚Äîin the first ~10 seconds before thought even forms.

That's why meditation doesn't work. That's why journaling doesn't work. That's why "reframing" doesn't work.

By the time you're aware you're spiraling, the shame response has already hijacked your nervous system.

You need something that works in that 7-second window. Before the loop starts. Before your brain locks onto "Did they see I'm inadequate?"

That's what The Shift does. It activates your vagus nerve in a 90-second pattern that interrupts the shame response before it becomes a thought.

Talk soon,

Anna

Understanding Your Pattern: {{ $('Webhook').item.json.query.quiz_result_title }}

You're a {{ $('Webhook').item.json.query.quiz_result_title }}. (I scored 9/10. Same pattern.)

When I analyzed 296 quiz responses, I found 4 distinct overthinker patterns:

  • The Mindful Thinker ‚Äî You reflect, but rarely spiral
  • The Gentle Analyzer ‚Äî You think a lot; sometimes it leaks into worry
  • The Chronic Overthinker ‚Äî Your mind loops often. You crave peace, but certainty feels safer
  • The Overthinkaholic ‚Äî Your brain never clocks out. You don't need more plans; you need a reset

You're {{ $('Webhook').item.json.query.quiz_result_title }}. So am I.

Here's what I noticed:

Our minds loop. We replay conversations. Analyze every word. Wonder if they noticed something was off.

I did this for 8 years. Good therapy. It helped me understand why I overthink. But it didn't stop me from lying awake at 3AM, replaying an awkward moment from a meeting.

Because overthinkers don't just worry about the future. We replay the past. Over and over.

And shame operates pre-consciously. By the time you're aware you're replaying, the loop has already started.

That 7-second window is where The Shift lives. It interrupts the shame response before it hijacks your night.

Talk soon,

Anna
